text:
1907. Lowes, R.H.
Assiniboia.

Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can. It will be sent to Saskatchewan Archives, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name: R. H. LOWES
Address: ASSINIBOIA, SKASK.
Birthplace: CATTARO, CANADA

1. Introductory Questions:
   What year did you start homesteading in eastern Canada? 1907
   Where did you set up homesteading? ASSINIBOIA, SKASK.
   How far had you been living before that? MOOSE JAW
   For how many people did you prepare meals? ME
   How far was it to your nearest store? 5 MILES
   How often could a visit be made to the store? ANNUALLY
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   BAKING SODA, CORN SYRUP, DRIED APPLES, RAISINS,
   PIE RAISINS, SUGAR, SALT, BAKING POWDER, PEPPER,
   SARDINES, BUTTER

2. Flour and Other Grain Products:
   In what quantities did you buy? 100 lbs. SACK
   What was the annual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.25
   How much did you use cracked flour? ME
   Whole wheat flour? ME
   Was flour milled locally? YES
   That was the price for a twenty pound bag of flour? $1.45
   What other grain products did you use?
   Cornmeal? ME
   Other? ME

3. Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? LATER IN THE YEARS
   How did you grind it? COFFEE GRINDER
1907. Lowes, R.H.
Assiniboia.

A QUESTIONNAIRE

Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and will fit.

Name: R. H. LOWES
Address: ASSINIBOIA, CANADA
Birthplace: CANADA, CANADA

1. INTERESTING FACTS

What year did you start your housekeeping? In northern Canada? 1907.
Where did you set up housekeeping? ASSINIBOIA, SASKATCHEWAN.
Have you been living here since then? MOOSE JAW.
For how many years have you been living there? 5 YEARS.
How far is it to your nearest store? 2 MILES.
How often do you visit the store? EVERY WEEK.
What products did you usually buy in those early years?
BAKING GOODS, CORN SYRUP, DRIED APPLES, RAISINS, TEA, COFFEE, BUTTER, SARDINES, SUGAR, SALT, BAKING POWDER, PEPPER.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

In what quantities did you buy flour? 100 LBS. EACH.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of flour? $3.00.
How much did you use per month? NONE.
Was flour milled locally? YES.
Was flour milled locally? NO.
What was the price for a barrel of flour? $14.50.
What other grain products did you use? NONE.
Corncakes? NONE.
Oats? NONE.
Did you grind your own wheat for pancakes? NO.
How did you grind it? WITH A MILLER.
1907. Lowes, R.H.
Assiniboia.

Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can. It will be sent to Saskatchewan Archives, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name: R. H. Lowes
Address: Assiniboia, Sask.
Birthplace: Cataract, Canada

1. Introductory Questions:
   - What year did you start homesteading in eastern Canada? 1907
   - Where did you set up housekeeping? Assiniboia, Sask.
   - How far had you been living before that? Moose Jaw
   - For how many people did you prepare meals? ME
   - How far was it to your nearest store? 5-6 miles
   - How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week
   - What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
     Baking Soda, Corn Syrup, Dried Apples, Raisins, Pie Filling, Sugar, Salt, Baking Powder, Pepper, Sardines, Butter

2. Flour and Other Grain Products:
   - What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ME
   - In what quantities did you buy? 1/4 lb. bags, sacks
   - Was there any price per hundred pounds of white flour? 5¢ per lb.
   - How much did you use cracked flour? ME
   - Whole wheat flour? ME
   - Was flour milled locally? YES
   - What was the price for a twenty pound bag of flour? 1.75¢
   - What other grain products did you use? ME
   - Cornmeal? ME
   - Other? ME
   - Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? LATER IN THE YEARS
   - How did you grind it? Coffee grinder
1907. Lowes, R.H.
Assiniboia.

Name: R. H. LOWES
Address: ASSINIBOIA, MAN.
Birthplace: CANADA

1. INTERESTING QUESTIONS

What year did you start your homesteading in eastern Canada? 1907.

Where did you set up housekeeping? ASSINIBOIA, MAN.

Have you been living there since then? YES.

For how many years have you been living there? 5 YEARS.

How far is it to your nearest store? 5 MILES.

How often do you visit the store? EVERY WEEK.

What products did you usually buy in those early years?

BAKING GOODS, CORN SYRUP, DRIED APPLES, RAISINS, SARDINES, SUGAR, SALT, BAKING POWDER, PEPPER.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

How much flour did you use in the early years? 100 LBS.

In what quantities did you buy flour? 100 LBS.

Was flour milled locally? YES.

What was the price per hundred pounds of flour? $2.50.

Did you purchase other grain products? YES.

What other grain products did you use? CORNMEAL.

Did you grind your own wheat for flour? NO.

How did you grind it? WITH A MILL.

Did you raise your own wheat for flour? NO.

How did you grind it? WITH A MILL.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy? (in lbs.) ... 100 lbs.

What was the price per lb.? ... $2.50

What brand of sugar did you use? ... EDWARDS

What size of tin or syrup did you purchase? ... 10 lbs.

At what price? ... $4.80

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? ... NONE

Butter? ... AT THE STORE

That was the price of butter? ... $1.00

Did you make butter? ... NO

Did you make cheese? ... YES

What kind of cheese? ... NONE

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ... BEEF

How did you get fresh meat? ... FROM NEIGHBORS

How often did you get fresh meat? ... EVERY WEEK

Was there a "meat ring" in your neighborhood? ... NO

If so, what year was it organized? ... 1910

Did you use game? ... YES

For how long? ... NOT KNOWN

What part did fish play in the family diet? ... FRESH

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? ... FRESH

What kind? ... WHOLE FISH, PIECE, SUCTION

7. **VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS**

     - Potatoes **YES**

   - How did you buy prunes? (In bulk or by the box)? **BY BOX**

   - Learn to make?

8. **PRESERVING**

   - That year did you first preserve meat by canning? **NO**

6. **BEVERAGES**

   What kind of tea did you buy? **TEA**.  
   What kind of coffee did you buy? **COFFEE**.

   That other beverage was what? **MILK**.  
   Price? **$1.00**.

   **ANSWER:** Yes.

   Potatoes **12/12**.

   Turnips **12/12**.  
   Beets **12/12**.

   In what quantities did you buy white navy beans?

   What was the price of prunes? **$1.00**.

   What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, lumberrries, raisins, currants or other)?

8. **PRESERVING**

   In the future will you make any foods by canning? **YES**.

   Other foods? **NONE**.

   Beans? **NO**.

   This year did you first preserve fruit by canning? **12/12**.

   That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? **12/12**.

   That year did you first preserve meat by canning? **12/12**.

   Do you still can your food by canning or drying? **YES**.

   To what extent? **FULLY**.

   Did you make your own vinegar? **NO**.

That kind of tea did you buy? TEA... SAKAHAH... As what price? $7.48.

Price? ...$1.50

apricots, peaches, laranberries, rhubarb, currants or others)?

Reason? ...YES... because? ...YES... Sasha loona?

Was there any shortage which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.

People in the early days did not have the money to dig wells. In late years some dug wells by hand and got drinking water and some drilled wells. It was mostly all well water very few dug wells here too. Good drinking water.

If so, was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank)

People in the early days did not have the money to dig wells, and got drinking water from springs or streams.

Very few dug wells. Few had good drinking water.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If you made your own, did you use lye? What kind of laundry soap did the crease contain? 

14. FUEL

15. HEATING

By whom was your first cook stove made? Didn't know. 

What year was it purchased? 1977 

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Tin 

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) Earthenware 

When did you first see lead paint? 1865 

Aluminum? 1914

No COMMENT

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

BREAKFAST: Oatmeal Porridge, Baking Powder Biscuits

Some Syrup, Some Melted Butter, Rasins, Potatoes

@ syrup Bannock, 34 tsp Potatoes & Fish

Winter Months

From 1906-1912

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in winter? Include the menu. List other present and place their approximate ages at the time.

I would say 1914 Roast Goose, Plum Pudding

Potatoes & Apple Pie

At That Time The money The Bannock was very scarce

from 20 to 30 years ago

19. Have you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Well I have seen the day that a Pan of Bannock looked awful good to me
No COMMENT

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest
year you can remember. Give the year and list the approximate number of
each item used at the time. State the approximate number, e.g., dinner
or breakfast.

BREAKFAST: Oatmeal Porridge Baking Powder Biscuits

Some Baked Beans MEAT: Barbecued Beef or Ham

@ (sp?) Bannock. 3 cups Potatoes & Flour

White Flour Muffins

From 1906 to 1912.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?
Give the name, date, place present and type of dish served.

I served my first Christmas dinner in 1914. The menu included:

- Turkey
- Cranberry sauce
- Green beans
- Potatoes
- Rolls

19. Have you ever refused to almost starvation level living on one or two
local / produced foods? Give details.

Well I have been the only thing I could get to live.

Pan of Bannock cooked on the fire.
21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details as possible.)

When I got married in 1918

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of Butler growing and gathering foods in other ways than pioneer days in Vermont. When I first married in 1918
